entry.title: 9 Things You Need to Know About SAP Community at SAP TechEd in Berlin
entry.content:
9 Things You Need to Know About SAP Community at SAP TechEd in Berlin 

SAP TechEd in Berlin is just around the corner and it‚Äôs not your typical tech conference: it‚Äôs where SAP Community comes home. To help you make the most of your time on-site, here are 9 must-know ways to experience the community in action. 

1. Connect at the Community Clubhouse 

Think of this as your community hub. It‚Äôs the place to meet other members alongside the SAP Community team, swap ideas, share experiences, and just hang out with people who are as passionate about SAP as you are.  Come join your community in Hall 1.2  

2. Dive into the Developer Garage 

The Developer Garage is a hands-on playground where you can work alongside Developer Advocates on real projects. With 7 tracks and 32 tutorials, it‚Äôs the perfect space to get practical experience and try out the latest SAP technologies. 

3. Learn from the Experts 

From product owners in AI, ABAP, and CAP to SAP Champions and Mentors, the ‚ÄúMeet the Experts‚Äù tables are where you can ask questions, get insights, and gain practical tips straight from the people building SAP solutions. 

4. Explore the Community Theatre 

Catch 33 community talks, participate in trivia competitions, and check out the DemoJam at the end of Day 1 (15:00‚Äì16:15 Berlin time, session DJ1295), hosted by Mr. Bluebeard himself. Teams will have 6 minutes to tackle a real business challenge using SAP BTP, showcasing innovation, creativity, and fun. Stop by the Community Clubhouse to see who takes home the DemoJam trophy.  

5. Explore Learning and Certification Opportunities 

SAP TechEd in Berlin offers a dedicated space for certifications. Learn what certifications are available, understand their value, and even take free onsite certification exams for SAP Generative AI Developer and SAP Build Developer in Berlin, Bangalore, or Louisville. Find more details and register for the exam. 

6. Step into the SAP TechEd Experience Center 

Discover the future of enterprise technology, from Business AI to live robotic demos. Experience gamified learning, explore customer use cases, and take home a smart tag and learning badge to continue your journey long after the event.  Make your way to Hall 3.2 for all the experience center has to offer. 

7. Get to Know the SAP Community Platform 

Whether you‚Äôre new or seasoned, the SAP Community info space will help you navigate the platform, find groups, and even learn how to become an event organizer or start a local location group. 

8. Connect with Mentors and Champions 

Curious about the SAP Mentors or SAP Champions programs? Stop by booth 103 in the Clubhouse, learn about the programs, and discover how you can become more involved in the community. 

9. Don‚Äôt Miss the Developer Keynote 

The developer keynote is a highlight for anyone interested in the latest innovations and the roadmap of SAP technologies. 

SAP TechEd in Berlin isn‚Äôt just about sessions and workshops, it‚Äôs about being part of the SAP Community in real life. Whether you‚Äôre rolling up your sleeves in a hands-on tutorial, swapping stories at a casual meetup, or catching insights from an expert talk, every corner of the event is designed to help you connect, share, and grow alongside fellow community members. 

We can‚Äôt wait to see you there! Come ready to learn, share, and be part of the SAP Community energy ü§ù

entry.title: Re: I want to see the relevant Billing documents for a sa...
entry.content:
Hi Ramuy,
As you explain the relevant billing documents for sales order in sales volume flexible analysis is not included. To include credit and debit memos in the Sales Volume ‚Äì Flexible Analysis app, you need to adjust the selection criteria and ensure the correct key figures and document categories are enabled in the report configuration.

Steps to Include Credit and Debit Memos in the Report
Check the Document Category Filters The Flexible Analysis app (F1250) may default to showing only standard billing documents (e.g., invoices). To include credit and debit memos, the app and go to the filter bar.

Add or adjust the filter for Billing Document Type or Document Category.

Include types like:

  • L2 ‚Äì Credit Memo
  • L1 ‚Äì Debit Memo
  • S1 ‚Äì Cancellation Invoice (if relevant)

Enable Relevant Key Figures Some key figures like Net Value of Credit Memos or Net Value of Debit Memos are not shown by default.

Click on the gear icon or ‚ÄúSettings‚Äù in the report.

Add key figures such as,

  • Net Value of Credit Memos
  • Net Value of Debit Memos
  • Sales Volume Quantity (adjusted) ‚Äì if available, this includes credit/debit adjustments.

Hope the above explanation help you.

entry.title: Unable to exclude BankDetails segment from Business Partner replication in S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hi all,

I‚Äôm currently working on an S/4HANA Public Cloud ‚Üí SAP EWM integration using the standard communication arrangement SAP_COM_0008 (Business Partner, Customer and Supplier Integration).

During testing, I noticed that bank information of suppliers is automatically included in the outbound payload, even though this data should not be shared with EWM.

Below is an excerpt of the payload (from the interface BusinessPartnerSUITEBulkReplicateRequest

<BankDetails actionCode="04"> <ID>0001</ID> <BankDirectoryReference> <BankStandardID>ABNANL2A</BankStandardID> <BankCountryCode>NL</BankCountryCode> <BankInternalID>ABNANL2A</BankInternalID> </BankDirectoryReference> <BankAccountStandardID>NL27ABNA0617417393</BankAccountStandardID> <ValidityPeriod> <StartDate>2025-10-14</StartDate> <EndDate>9999-12-31</EndDate> </ValidityPeriod> </BankDetails>

These are the fields that are sent by default:

  • BankStandardID (BIC)

  • BankCountryCode

  • BankInternalID

  • BankAccountStandardID (IBAN)

  • ID (bank record ID)

  • ValidityPeriod

Issue:

In DRF (Data Replication Framework) I reviewed both the Main Filters and Segment Filters under the replication model 986_000 (Business Partner).
While I can maintain filters for company code, sales area, tax grouping, etc., there is no segment filter for Bank Details (BUT0BK) visible.
This means the <BankDetails> segment is always replicated.

Screenshots from my system show:

  • Main filters: LIFNR, BUKRS, EKORG, KTOKK, PARTNER, etc.

  • Segment filters: tax, company code, sales area, address usage, but no entry for BankDetails.

Question:

Is there any standard way (in S/4HANA Public Cloud) to exclude or suppress the BankDetails segment from Business Partner outbound replication?

I would like to avoid sending IBAN/BIC data to external or decentralized systems like EWM.
I can‚Äôt find a DRF filter object for it, and I‚Äôd prefer not to implement a custom BAdI unless absolutely necessary.

Any official guidance, SAP Note, or workaround (e.g., via Communication Arrangement setup, DRF customizing, or CDS-based filtering) would be very helpful.

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Re: üü° Fun for Week 2: Petoberfest üê±üê∂üêµüê∑üêªüê∏üêîüê¥ü¶¨ü¶éüê†ü¶úüêßüêåüêõ
MCP: A Comprehensive Guide
entry.content:
What You‚Äôll Learn in this Guide

In this comprehensive guide to the Model Context Protocol (MCP), we explore how MCP simplifies AI integrations by standardizing the way AI systems connect with external tools and data sources.

By the end, you‚Äôll understand how MCP transforms complex, one-off integrations into a seamless, interoperable ecosystem.

We‚Äôll cover:

Why MCP: The Problem with AI Integrations
What is MCP
MCP Architecture: Host, Client, and Server
Demo

1) Why MCP

To understand why the Model Context Protocol (MCP) matters, we need to trace the evolution from LLMs to AI Agents, and then to MCP as the missing interoperability layer.

1.1 The Problem with LLMs

While powerful, Large Language Models (LLMs) have four critical limitations:

Outdated knowledge
No access to external or real-time data
Limited context windows
Risks of hallucination

1.2 From LLMs to AI Agents

To overcome these challenges, AI Agents emerged ‚Äî capable of accessing tools, invoking APIs, and making real-time decisions.

However, this evolution created a new problem: integration complexity.
Each AI agent or application needed custom integrations with multiple APIs, data sources, and tools ‚Äî leading to fragmented, brittle connections.

1.3 The Problem with Agents Accessing Tools

In the traditional approach, every model must directly integrate with every tool ‚Äî an M√óN problem.

Example:
3 AI models √ó 3 tools = 9 separate connections.
Each integration is custom-built and non-reusable, resulting in a fragile and hard-to-maintain web of connections.

This approach doesn‚Äôt scale. As the number of AI models and tools grows, integration overhead increases.

Solution ‚Äî The MCP Approach

MCP replaces the M√óN complexity with a simple, scalable M+N model.

Each AI model and each tool integrates once with the MCP layer.
This single standard interface allows any AI model to access any tool seamlessly ‚Äî without custom connectors.

In short, MCP turns AI integration from a one-off engineering effort into a plug-and-play ecosystem for tools, data, and intelligence.

2) What is MCP

MCP (Model Context Protocol) is an open-source standard that defines how AI applications communicate with external systems through a unified interface.

It enables interoperability between different AI agents, tools, and platforms ‚Äî regardless of their language, framework, or runtime environment.

With MCP, developers can build AI solutions that dynamically discover and invoke new tools securely and consistently.

3) MCP Architecture: Host, Client, and Server

MCP follows a client-server architecture similar to web protocols, but tailored for AI interaction.

It consists of three main components:

MCP Host ‚Äî Manages and exposes available tools

MCP Client ‚Äî Initiates requests to discover and use tools

MCP Server ‚Äî Implements tool capabilities and exposes them to clients

3.1 MCP Server core capabilities

3.2 Interaction Model

The following diagram illustrates the interaction between the Host, MCP Server, and MCP Client.

This modular structure allows AI systems to dynamically discover, invoke, and orchestrate tools through a standardized layer ‚Äî without direct coupling between tools and models.

3.3 Real-World Example: SAP MCP Servers

SAP has released MCP (Model Context Protocol) servers for CAP (Cloud Application Programming Model), UI5, and Fiori development environments.

With these MCP servers, AI agents can now assist developers contextually ‚Äî understanding project structure, metadata, and domain models to offer precise, real-time help in CAP, Fiori, and UI5 projects.

This demonstrates how MCP can be embedded into enterprise ecosystems, bridging AI assistance with actual business development workflows.

4) Demo

The following demo illustrates these concepts in action:
https://github.tools.sap/I572601/mcp-demo

Demo 1 shows the integration challenges without MCP.
Demo 2 demonstrates how MCP simplifies integration and tool discovery through a unified protocol.

These demos make the shift from manual, fragile integrations to MCP-driven automation immediately clear.

Key Takeaways

MCP simplifies AI integrations by replacing point-to-point connections with a single standard interface.
Interoperability is built-in ‚Äî any AI agent can use any MCP-compliant tool.
Scalability improves as new tools or models can be added without re-engineering integrations.

entry.title: SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model (SAP PaPM Cloud UM) Writing to S/4 HANA Public Cloud using SOAP API
entry.content:
Hi Everyone,

As you read the blog post's title, I'm sure you're excited to get to the interesting section where you'll discover how to use SOAP Service to write to SAP S/4 HANA Cloud.

The public cloud version of SAP S/4 HANA offers equivalent SOAP APIs, which can be leveraged in the Universal Model. This flexibility enables you posting documents not just in SAP S/4 HANA On-premise, but also in the SAP S/4 HANA Cloud.

For more information, see SAP S/4 HANA Public Cloud SOAP APIs.

Now allow me to demonstrate your prerequisites and procedures.

Prerequisites

  • You must have an existing SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model subscription. More information, Account Setup.
  • You must have an existing SAP S/4 HANA Public Cloud.

Scenario

You were able to read data records from SAP S/4 HANA Public Cloud in context of the recent blog post SAP PaPM Cloud Standard and Universal Model OData Integration with S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Now, you are required to sent back the calculated data records from Universal Model using SOAP Service.

Procedure

1.     Creation of Communication User and System

You may follow the same approach of the Creation of Communication User and System from the mentioned blog post above on our scenario but without ticking the box Inbound Only.

Then add a User for Inbound and Outbound Communication.

For more information about the procedure, see Create a Communication System with Inbound and Outbound Users.

2.     Creation of Communication Arrangements

For this blog post, let‚Äôs use the Journal Entry by Ledger ‚Äì Post (Asynchronous).

In the procedure from the official documentation of Create Communication Arrangement. Proceed on creation of Communication Arrangement.

3.     Creation of Destination

Create the Destination according to the configuration that you have created from previous steps.

Fields

Values

Name

S4HC_DEST

Type

HTTP

Description

Destination for using SOAP Service SAP S/4 HANA Public Cloud

Proxy Type

Internet

URL

<api-url of your communication arrangements>

Authentication

BasicAuthentication

User

<Your Communication User>

Password

<Your Communication Password>

Additional Properties

sap-client :<your s4hc client>

For reference, see image below.

4.     Creation of Connection

Since you already have the Destination, you may now proceed on the creation of Connection in Universal Model.

For the Journal Entry by Ledger - Post (Asynchronous), you may refer for the Models and Fields that are being used for the General Ledger posting.

If you want more detailed fields that I have added, please refer to SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model (SAP PaPM Cloud UM) Posting Strategy via SOAP Services as it uses the same use case for Journal Entry.

Once all Models and Fields are configured, you may now proceed on pressing the Sync Models button to generate the Model Entities that will be used as a Result Model function in your Writer.

For more information, see Manage Connections.

5.     Setting up of Writer function

You can maintain the Connection created from previous procedures and Model in your Writer function.

Configure the mapping of fields according to what you have added from previous procedures.

With this configuration, when you Run the Writer function, it will generate a Message ID that we can check in SAP S/4 HANA Cloud.

6.     Validation of Posting in SAP S/4 HANA Public Cloud

In the SAP S/4 HANA Public Cloud Message Monitoring for Administrators, you will be seeing an Interface /FINANCE ‚Äì JRNLENTRIN ‚Äì 00001 that you can open to search the Message ID from generated from Universal Model.

Once opened, search the Message ID.

It will show the status of posting and returns the Document number accordingly by SAP S/4 HANA Public Cloud.

Disclaimer: All data like Connection names, message IDs, document numbers and other examples are our dummy records. And this is only to showing how you can use SOAP Service in Universal Model.

And that will be it for this blog post! I hope you have learned now how you can setup the writing of SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model to your SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Public Cloud.

See you again onto the next topic!

entry.title: Re: SAP CAP Deep Insert on draft table
entry.content:
Hi,

i solved in this way:

I get the current parent draft entity in this way:

const oDraft = await SELECT.one.from(Cases.drafts).where(`ID='${req.params[0]["ID"]}' and HasActiveEntity=false`);
 
then I set the children (a case has a composition of multiple versions and a version has a composition of multiple systems)
//set parent properties
oDraft.title = "test";
oDraft.description = "test descr";
//set children (I use the DraftAdministrativeData_DraftUUID assigned the the current parent)
oDraft.versions = [{name: "test1", description:"test desc 1", DraftAdministrativeData_DraftUUID: oDraft.DraftAdministrativeData_DraftUUID, systems:[{sid:1,hostName:"host 1",DraftAdministrativeData_DraftUUID: oDraft.DraftAdministrativeData_DraftUUID},{sid:2,hostName:"host 2",DraftAdministrativeData_DraftUUID: oDraft.DraftAdministrativeData_DraftUUID}]}]
//udpate the draft
await UPDATE(Cases.drafts,{ID:req.params[0]["ID"], HasActiveEntity:false}).with(oDraft);
 
hope this helps
Regards
Roberto

entry.title: Connecting Non-SAP Systems with SAP BTP: APIs, Event Mesh & Integration Suite
entry.content:
Connecting Non-SAP Systems with SAP BTP: APIs, Event Mesh & Integration Suite

Integration is one of the top priorities for SAP customers in 2025. As hybrid IT landscapes grow , combining SAP S/4HANA, legacy systems, and modern SaaS, the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) has become the central layer enabling these systems to talk to each other securely and in real time.

SAP‚Äôs Integration Suite, Event Mesh, and API Management together form the backbone of this connected ecosystem.

 

1. Why Integration Matters More Than Ever

Businesses rarely run fully on SAP alone. You might have Salesforce for CRM, Workday for HR, or custom-built logistics apps. These need to work seamlessly and tirelessly with SAP without faults, sharing customer data, triggering workflows, and ensuring real-time visibility across the value chain.

BTP helps unify all this through open connectors, APIs, and event-driven communication, without touching the core of SAP S/4HANA.

 

2. Integration Suite: The Foundation Layer

SAP Integration Suite offers a unified set of capabilities to design, manage, and monitor integrations between SAP and non-SAP systems.

Cloud Integration
For process-based, message-driven integration between SAP and non-SAP systems. It enables data flow through pre-built integration packages (for example, SAP ‚Üí Salesforce ‚Üí SAP), reducing development time.

API Management
Expose custom APIs from CAP-based apps or legacy systems, and consume REST APIs from third-party platforms. You can control access, apply rate limits, and ensure security via OAuth and API policies.

Integration Advisor
Suggests mappings and interface structures automatically, saving time and improving consistency during design.

Together, these tools simplify how business processes flow across a hybrid landscape.

 

3. Event Mesh: Making Systems Talk in Real Time

SAP Event Mesh introduces an event-driven architecture (EDA) , enabling systems to communicate through business events rather than constant API calls.

External systems can exchange data with SAP applications
When a customer creates an order in a non-SAP app, Event Mesh can instantly notify SAP S/4HANA or a CAP app to start fulfillment.

Processes stay synchronized in real time
Inventory changes, shipment updates, or status alerts are instantly propagated to every connected system , keeping everyone on the same page with standardized information and data.

You avoid modifying S/4HANA directly
By handling custom logic in BTP extensions and event subscribers, you reduce technical debt and simplify upgrades. The clean-core principle stays intact.

Event Mesh therefore acts as the ‚Äúnervous system‚Äù of the landscape, transmitting business signals instantly across applications.

 

4. APIs + Events = The Future of Integration

Modern integration combines APIs for control and events for awareness.
APIs handle structured, request-driven interactions (‚Äúget order details‚Äù), while events handle spontaneous updates (‚Äúorder created‚Äù).

Together, they enable loosely coupled architectures, where systems are connected, but not dependent.

 

5. Real-World Example: A Logistics Scenario

A German manufacturing company runs SAP S/4HANA for order processing, an on-premises warehouse management system (WMS), and a third-party shipping service that provides delivery tracking via REST APIs.

They use SAP BTP to integrate these three worlds, ensuring data consistency, real-time visibility, and a clean SAP core. Let‚Äôs see how the three pillars of integration make it work together.

 

Cloud Integration: The Process Connector

SAP Cloud Integration (part of Integration Suite) acts as the central traffic controller for data between S/4HANA and the warehouse system.

  • Whenever a sales order is created in S/4HANA, Cloud Integration picks up the outbound IDoc or OData event (for example, ‚ÄúSalesOrder.Created‚Äù).
  • It maps this order data into the format expected by the warehouse system, handling data transformations, enrichments, and protocol conversions (like IDoc ‚Üí REST).
  • The integration flow (iFlow) then securely transmits this data over HTTPS to the warehouse‚Äôs REST endpoint or message queue.
  • At the end of the day, the same flow also synchronizes stock levels or order confirmations back into S/4HANA.

This ensures both systems always have the same view of orders and inventory, without manual file transfers or custom scripts.

Result:
Process-based data exchange between SAP and non-SAP systems, fully automated and monitored from BTP.

 

Event Mesh: The Real-Time Messenger

While Cloud Integration handles batch or process-oriented data, Event Mesh ensures real-time responsiveness across the landscape.

  • When the warehouse system marks an order as ‚ÄúDelivered,‚Äù it publishes an event (for example, ‚ÄúDeliveryCreated‚Äù) to the SAP Event Mesh topic.
  • Event Mesh then pushes this event to all subscribed systems, such as the customer portal and CAP-based tracking app on BTP.
  • The subscriber apps instantly receive this update and can trigger follow-up actions, like sending a push notification or updating the customer‚Äôs order status on the web.

Unlike APIs that require constant polling, Event Mesh delivers updates asynchronously and only when needed, making the system more efficient and scalable.

Result:
Real-time synchronization without point-to-point dependencies, enabling instant reactions across systems.

 

API Management: The Secure Gateway

Now that multiple systems generate and consume data, API Management provides a unified and secure access layer for external consumption.

  • The company creates a custom ‚ÄúOrder Tracking‚Äù API that aggregates order and delivery data from both S/4HANA (via Cloud Integration) and the warehouse (via Event Mesh events).
  • This API is managed through SAP‚Äôs API Management service, where policies handle:
    • Security: OAuth 2.0, API keys, and JWT validation
    • Traffic Control: Rate limits, quota management
    • Monitoring: API usage analytics and latency reports
  • The customer portal or mobile app consumes this API securely, allowing users to track their orders end-to-end from a single interface.

Result:
A governed, standardized entry point for all external consumers hence reducing complexity while protecting sensitive business data.

 

6. Key Takeaway

Connecting SAP and non-SAP systems doesn‚Äôt have to mean complex middleware landscapes anymore.
With SAP BTP, Integration Suite, APIs, and Event Mesh provide a unified, scalable, and governed way to achieve cross-system connectivity, without sacrificing your clean-core principles.

Start with one process, make it event-driven, and expand from there.
Integration is no longer a project phase, it‚Äôs an ongoing capability that defines how modern enterprises operate.

 

#SAPBTP #IntegrationSuite #EventMesh #APIManagement #SAPArchitecture #CleanCore #SAPIntegration #EnterpriseArchitecture #DigitalTransformation #SAPDevelopers

entry.title: Re: RPCNETN0 page down button not working in subscreen
entry.content:
I Found the problem. It was in the code from SAP itself.

For the functionality to deal with the page-down button, SAP provided the variable for the number of lines shown or in the table and the variable for the number of lines to scroll down on the page-down button with the same value. When then determining the new line to show as first in the table control they subtract 1 from the other and 1. Resulting in the top line to be shown being the first line in the table, meaning that the page-down will never work.
Modified the SAP Code and the button is now working as it should.

entry.title: Re: How to automatically create an Email Interaction via...
entry.content:
Hello Esnowy

I have a similar use case where we send emails to contacts on a lead based on certain conditions and we also want an activity to be created for that. I have been successfully able to do that. A few things that I would check:

1. Does the contact have an email address maintained on the relationship between the account and contact that is on the ticket.

2. Is the workflow rule activated? (Just making sure üôÇ )

3. To create an email activity, you need to set the create activity toggle button in the workflow action step. 

4. Do you see anything in the workflow logs/ analysis?

After checking all the above, if you are still not getting email notifications and the activity is not getting created, I would report this to SAP C4C support for investigation.

One thing that I noticed is that the email activity thats gets created, only contains the subject from the subject from the email workflow. The email content is not populated in the email activity that gets created. You might want to check with SAP support and/ or with your sdk developers if they can somehow influence that, if that is a requirement ofcourse.

Julius

entry.title: 3 decimals used in a form template
entry.content:
Esure you have added 3 decimals in the scoping as required for some countries.

In the xml you see 3 decimals but the form shows only 2 decimals.

 Open the Form in ALD:

  • Launch Adobe LiveCycle Designer.
  • Open the form template you want to modify (e.g., invoice, purchase order).

  Select the Field:

  • Click on the numeric field (e.g., price, quantity, amount) that needs to show 3 decimals.

Set Field Type and Formatting:

  • In the Object palette, go to the Field tab.
  • Ensure the field type is set to Numeric Field.

Adjust Display Pattern:

  • Go to the Binding tab (or Value tab depending on ALD version).
  • Under Display Pattern, enter:
  • num{zzzz9.999}
  • This pattern ensures the number is shown with 3 decimal places.

  Optional: Set Edit and Data Patterns:

  • If users will input data, set the Edit Pattern similarly:
  • num{zzzz9.999}
  • For Data Pattern, you can also use the same format to ensure consistency.

Save and Deploy:

  • Save the form.
  • Upload it back to SAP ByD via the Application and User Management ‚Üí Form Templates section.

entry.title: SII tip for Spain #7: Error 1166 and Tax Procedures
entry.content:
In this blog, we share practical insights into specific features of the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance SII solution, focusing on Spanish localization requirements.

One recurring issue in Spain‚Äôs SII (Suministro Inmediato de Informaci√≥n) eDocument submission process is Error 1166, which relates to the validity of the VAT rate field (TipoImpositivo) in XML documents. This post explores the root causes of this error, its implications, and practical steps to resolve it.

 

Context

Recent cases involving intra-Community transactions revealed that documents submitted using a specific tax code configuration were being rejected by the Spanish Tax Authority. The error message returned was:

‚ÄúValor del campo TipoImpositivo no est√° incluido en la lista de valores permitidos‚Äù
(The value of the field TipoImpositivo is not included in the list of allowed values)

The most common cause of this error is that the invoice includes a VAT rate not recognized by the Tax Agency. You can find the valid VAT rates for Spain in the official list of Tipos impositivos de IVA.

In some cases, adjusting the tax code to reflect a valid VAT rate resolves the issue. However, in other scenarios, the root cause is more complex.

 

Root Cause

In countries like Germany, it is permissible to configure the tax procedure to determine intra-Community acquisition tax at 0% or with deductions over the usual input tax. For example, SAP Note 98181 - Acquisition tax and required Customizing explains how input tax (ESE) can reference output tax (ESA).

A typical configuration might define ESE as 100% of ESA, expecting it to result in 21% (i.e., 100% of 21% = 21%). However, in the SII process, this configuration results in an XML submission where the VAT rate is incorrectly interpreted as 100%.

Spain only recognizes specific VAT rates‚Äîtypically 21% (standard), 10% (reduced), and 4% (super-reduced). A rate of 100% is not valid under Spanish tax law, leading to rejection by the Tax Authority.

 

Solution

According to Spanish VAT regulations and the Tax Agency:

  • The VAT rate is the percentage applied to the tax base to calculate the tax amount (VAT 2024).
  • Intra-Community deliveries are exempt from VAT in the EU country of dispatch (Directive 2006/112/EC)
  • The supplier‚Äôs invoice should not include VAT but must reference Article 226.11 of Directive 2006/112/EC.
  • Intra-Community acquisitions are generally subject to VAT in the country of reception ( Articles 13.1¬∫ and 14 of the Spanish VAT Law).

 

In Spain, EU acquisitions must be reported as both output and input VAT in Form 303 (VAT return). Additionally, the recipient must have a valid intra-Community VAT number and report the transaction in Form 349, including the supplier‚Äôs VAT number.

The SII expects EU acquisitions to be registered as defined in FAQ 4.4 from the Tax Agency. Specifically:

  • The field ClaveR√©gimenEspecialOTrascendencia should be set to 09.
  • The deductible VAT amount should be reported in the CuotaDeducible field.

Since SII calculations are based on the tax base (BASB), the VAT rate associated with ESE is interpreted directly. If ESE is set to 100%, the XML will reflect this rate without transformation, triggering Error 1166.

 

The expected tax procedure configuration for Spain is as follows:

The typical Intra Community acquisitons Tax Code should be configured as follows:

 

The documents posted with the  EU Acquisions tax code should be similar to:

 

 The XML submitted to the Tax Agency will follow the SII guidelines:

 

In summary...

To ensure compliance and avoid similar issues:

  • Use only the VAT rates allowed by the Tax Agency.. Valid tax rates include 21%, 10%, and 4%.  A rate of 100% is not accepted.  See Tipos impositivos de IVA.
  • Ensure that the steps in the tax procedure always reference the tax base amount (BASB).

 

Additional information

In case of additional questions, you can visit the SII help documentation in the following links:

  • Electronic Tax Register Books with SII in S/4HANA Public Cloud
  • Electronic Tax Register Books with SII in S/4HANA Private Cloud
  • Electronic Tax Register Books with SII in ERP

Other SII tips:

  • Spain - SAP Document and Reporting Compliance -> Related Links -> Community section

Disclaimer

This blog post is based on a generalized case study and is intended for informational purposes only. Configuration recommendations should be validated within your system landscape and aligned with your organization‚Äôs implementation partner. For specific guidance, consult your legal or tax advisor and refer to official SAP documentation.

entry.title: Development of client-facing app in SAP BTP - Authentication and User management
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I am working on the development of an SAPUI5 application in SAP BTP using SAP Business Application Studio. The idea is that this application will be deployed using SAP Build Workzone, Standard edition. This application acts like a simple portal where a small subset of the company's customers (~5 customers, which themselves are also companies) will need to access from outsite the organization where the app will be hosted. Based on the logged in user, the portal will display data regarding to the business partner that user represents (this I believe a mapping between the user and the BP code in SAP is enough). The Odata service itself is not that complex (in the sense that will retrieve sales data for the customer, so it's pretty much an Odata service that will retrieve data from sales tables like VBAK, VBAP, etc. For context, I'm working with a on-premise ECC EHP7 backend. An high level diagram of the development is as below:

 

‚ÄÉ

As I am fairly new to BTP Identity solutions, I believe that the main point here is regarding the expositure of this app in SAP BTP for people outside the organization (third party access). One of the requirements is that the management of the credentials for these customers would be done entirely on my organization's side, for better control: we would not want anyone with access to the app to request an user account there.

There are a handful of possibilites, but i'd like to understand what would be the best approaches (or at least an combination of approaches). I thought of the following approaches:

1) try to manage the authentication with a developed user service - besides being less safe, I believe this is not possible due to the security layet BTP itself has, so you'd need to have a valid user to authenticate with BTP before accessing the portal.

2) Use SAP Identity Authentication Service (IAS alone), with its Local User Store and without both Self Service registration and Social Identity Providers - Users would be created by administrators, and the password sent to them, in a similar fashion to what's done with service keys for Integration Suite scenarios. Similar to the scenario in https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/business-to-business-scenario?locale=en-US, considering a single user per customer (or even https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/business-to-consumer-scenario?locale=en-US without the possibility of the user creating an access to themselves

3) Use SAP Cloud Identity Services (not only IAS) to manage the integration with the corporate identity provider of the organization i'm working (Microsoft Entra ID). I believe this can be more complex as we'd shift the control of the user maintenance to the organization's Identity Provider, so some sort of federation/trust would be required between SAP Cloud Identity Services and Entra ID.

 
This looks like a common (or at least, not very uncommon) scenario, so I would appreciate guidances or suggestions on the best path for this auth.
 
Thanks in Advance,
Erick Grilo.

entry.title: Re: Enabling Multiple Instances (Bulk) processing on a custom Migration Object
entry.content:
Hello Andrew,

RULE_IS_S4H_CLOUD_P is a project rule (suffix _P). Subproject (_S) and Project rules will only be copied from original delivery project into the Z-project if a migration object that uses this rule (mainly in object or sub project rules) is added to the project.

What SAP S/4HANA release are you running?
This rule is marked OBSOLETE with 2025 release and will only be used in retired objects. Means the status is invalid and cannot be used anymore within objects.
Within 2023 it is still available. Try to add one of the following objects to your Z-Project: SIF_PRODUCT, SIF VENDOR_2, SIF_INTORDER_2.
That may help.

Another question. Does your API support bulk processing and handles the specific error message for bulk? Is it an own function module or an SAP function module?

Your FM must be compatible with the bulk handling of the migration cockpit.

BR

Frank

entry.title: Re: FexibleSearch returns null for localized name when ev...
entry.content:
To retrieve other localized field even if they are empty, you need to use outer join on the column. 

similar problem what i had with localized name retrieval : 

SELECT {c.pk},{c:name[en]},{c:name[de]},{c:name[nl]},{c:name[fr]},{c:name[sk]}
FROM {Category AS c}
WHERE ({c:name[en]} IS NULL OR {c:name[en]} = '')
AND {c.catalogVersion} IN (<list of catalogversion pks>)
ORDER BY {c.pk}

change to 

SELECT {c.pk},{c:name[en]:o},{c:name[de]:o},{c:name[nl]:o},{c:name[fr]:o},{c:name[sk]:o}
FROM {Category AS c}
WHERE ({c:name[en]:o} IS NULL OR {c:name[en]:o} = '')
AND {c.catalogVersion} IN (<list of catalogversion pks>)
ORDER BY {c.pk}

and then it gives all the column

entry.title: Second Half 2025 Release: What's new for SAP SuccessFactors Performance & Goals?
entry.content:
Performance reviews, feedback, and goal setting are essential to employee development, but they can often feel time-consuming, subjective, or lacking in real-world data. The second half 2025 product release is here (production date: Nov 14) to solve these challenges and has several exciting innovations for SAP SuccessFactors Performance & Goals, including the first SAP SuccessFactors AI agent. These innovations will transform performance and goal management, allowing your organization to move to a truly data-informed, AI-assisted approach to coaching, feedback, and workforce analytics.

Starting with the Performance and Goals Agent, which offers data-informed coaching for more meaningful conversations and performance reviews. This agent analyzes employee data, including performance goals, activities, achievements, and continuous feedback, to create a tailored discussion agenda for each employee.

Using Joule, managers receive AI-guided instant summaries on goal progress, key accomplishments, growth focus areas, and development recommendations. Then, managers can dive deeper and get focused insights on areas for improvement, development suggestions, and even smart recommendations on how employees can reach their goals. Your leaders can even ask for short, clear talking points to guide a respectful, confidence-building feedback conversation.

Performance and Goals Agent

Also available with this release are business rules in performance management, which trigger actions for users based on predefined conditions during the performance review process, such as dynamically exposing a comment field only when a rating condition is met. This standardized review process allows you to write powerful conditional logic that adapts in real-time, enhancing transparency, reducing bias, and ensuring that feedback aligns with organizational policies.

Business rules in performance management

Additionally, managers can use AI-generated comments for goals on the performance form to create well-crafted, insightful comments aligned with the ratings provided to their employees.

AI-generated comments for goals on performance forms

And employees can share their activities across different continuous performance management channels with both line and matrix managers. This engages all relevant stakeholders, creating a more collaborative and complete view of the employee‚Äôs development.

Activity sharing for continuous performance management

Also, with this release, you have access to pre-built use cases for the performance and goals area within People Intelligence in SAP Business Data Cloud, our new people analytics application. It empowers organizations to make smarter, faster decisions about their workforce and operations by unifying SAP and third-party data within SAP‚Äôs fully managed analytics platform. Designed to bring HR and business data together, People Intelligence offers intuitive dashboards, AI-assisted workforce insights supported by Joule, and hundreds of HR metrics with insights into many areas, such as performance tracking, and goal alignment with business strategy. By centralizing clean, well-organized HR data and layering in powerful AI capabilities, People Intelligence helps organizations make better decisions and act faster.

Performance insights dashboard

The future of HR is about personalized coaching, unbiased feedback, and data-driven performance management that drives clarity and connection. By aligning performance data, AI-guided insights, and clear business rules, SAP SuccessFactors is ensuring that every employee discussion contributes directly to both individual growth and organizational success.

Discover more 2H 2025 innovations across the suite by checking out the release highlights brochure, overview video featuring Bianka Woelke, and much more on the Product Release & Road Map Information page.

entry.title: Recovery of amortization in the event of a revaluation
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

We are changing the valuation of bonds from the acquisition cost principle to amortized cost, whereby premiums/discounts are amortized. The amortization since the acquisition of the bond up to the changeover date must be made up in one lump sum and posted to the income statement.

Is there a standard transaction in SAP TRM where this entry can be made and which also correctly calculates the premium/discount balance for the period after the valuation change?

 

Example:

Purchase of bond on September 30, 2020 at 101% (=10,100,000), nominal value 10,000,000

The amortization from September 30, 2020, to December 31, 2025, should be manually adjusted and posted (the amount is calculated outside of SAP).

Simplified assumption: ‚Ç¨50,000 premium is posted once. This leaves a premium of ‚Ç¨50,000 as of December 31, 2025, which is then amortized monthly using TPM1 until maturity.

Thank you!

entry.title: Re: Equivalent of: Call Function... In update task
entry.content:
I think your only 'clean-core' option for now is to use BGPF (the uncontrolled version). Within the method, you can call the MODIFY ENTITIES to create the billing document. Afterwards, call the COMMIT ENTITIES and see the response if there are any errors. And then subsequently, update the custom table at the last stage. The probability of the custom table update failing is very low.

If you do not want to use BGPF, what you can do is called the MODIFY ENTITIES from a custom action, then call the CONVERT KEY statement in the save_modified to retrieve the generated billing document and subsequently update the custom table.

I am not sure if there is any other way to do it as of the moment. I have tested the different variations and some of them fail due to some restrictions in the RAP framework.

entry.title: Introduction to Action Interface in SAP Signavio Process Governance
entry.content:
In today's fast-paced business environment, organizations are constantly seeking ways to streamline operations and empower a wider range of users to contribute to process automation. Our goal with the Action Interface is to make template actions for the most used script use cases, enabling more people to model workflows without coding, democratizing process automation for a broader audience. This blog post will introduce you to this powerful capability, focusing on its practical applications, strategic modelling tips, and use-case based insights.

The Credential Store

Before diving into actions, it's crucial to understand the Credential Store. This secret data repository is designed to securely store sensitive text, such as passwords or secret access keys, used by external systems. Credentials are encrypted with customer-specific keys and cannot be retrieved or changed by SAP Support, ensuring a high level of security. Operations involving credentials are also audit logged. This secure management of access tokens is not only a best practice for reducing the attack surface of your solution but is also used to restrict access to custom connectors. For instance, when integrating with SharePoint, client IDs and client secrets for Microsoft Entra ID authentication are stored as credentials in this store.

Configuring Actions

The Action Interface empowers organization administrators to configure various activities for use in workflows. Administrators navigate to the Organization settings from the user menu and then to the Activities tab to manage these configurations.

A key advantage is the ability to create multiple configurations for a single action type. This flexibility allows for tailored integrations specific to different needs within an organization, as implied by the "All configurations" lists available to administrators.

Example: SharePoint File Upload for Different Departments Consider the SharePoint File activity, which can be configured by an administrator. An administrator can create distinct configurations for various departments. By doing this, modelers in each department can simply select the pre-defined "SharePoint File Upload (Marketing)" or "SharePoint File Upload (Legal)" action in their workflows, making sure documents end up in the correct folder. This approach eliminates human error for upload task and time spend scripting integrations for modelling tasks.

Bringing Configurations Live

Once an administrator has configured and enabled these actions, workflow modelers can seamlessly incorporate them into their processes. From the process builder's Actions tab, modelers can select the External Activities tile and choose from the available, pre-configured actions like Model Guideline Check, SharePoint File Upload, or Sync to SAP Cloud ALM.

The modeler then maps the necessary input and output values for the selected configuration. For example:

  • A Model Guideline Check might take a "Model ID" as input and provide "Guideline check error" and "Guideline check warnings" as outputs.
  • For SharePoint File Upload, inputs might include the "Target folder" and the "Upload file", while the output could be a list of "Uploaded files" with their direct links.
  • The Sync to SAP Cloud ALM action similarly requires a "Model ID" and "Model Revision ID" as inputs to synchronize process model revisions from SAP Signavio to SAP Cloud ALM.

Example of Strategic Modelling

Streamlining SharePoint Document Upload and synchronise the process diagram with  Cloud ALM during an approval workflow.
Objective:
To ensure that approved business processes are stored in both SAP Signavio and Microsoft SharePoint, as required by some industry regulations. SharePoint helps provide proof of storage for audits. Once approved, the process is automatically synced with SAP Cloud ALM so it‚Äôs ready for implementation. This saves time, reduces manual work, and helps start projects faster and with more confidence.

Example workflow:

This workflow describes a process for managing and approving a guideline document with SAP Signavio Process Governance, with a focus on highlighting points where automated actions could be applied.

  1. Initial checks:
    • The result of the check determines the flow: If "Errors result," is NO errors the diagram state is set to "in progress", otherwise the process diagram is automatically rejected.
  1. This is followed by a manual Formal and Business Approval:
    • After the formal and business approval, an exclusive gateway determines the path:
      • If reject, the process leads to set process model state to "rejected" then terminates with a rejected end event.
      • If approve, the flow moves to the next step in the flow
  1. Parallel execution and automation focus:
    • The workflow then splits into a parallel gateway to execute two main streams:
      • Document management stream
        • SharePoint initial file delete .
        • SharePoint upload of the newly approved diagram.
      • SAP system integration stream:
        • Sync process diagram to SAP Cloud ALM with error handling
  • The parallel streams merge, and both successful and error paths lead to their respective final Approved end events. The key take-away for modelers is how automatic actions are used for state changes, system integrations (SharePoint, SAP Cloud ALM), and user notifications, to keep all systems updated and in sync.

Strategic Impact

  • Stronger compliance and governance: this automated process directly supports the strategic goal of data governance by ensuring that documents are properly maintained and synced across different systems.
  • Clear accountability: with built-in checks and approvals, you can trust that only quality, standards-compliant documents are published.
  • Faster decision-making: automated approval workflows speed up auto-rejections for administrative reasons and also speed-up approvals as they make updated information available to the approver during the approval process
  • Reduced manual effort and human error associated with complex document management tasks, leading to greater operational efficiency.
  • Faster project implementation: the updated process diagram is automatically synchronized with SAP Cloud ALM. This is important because Cloud ALM provides complete roadmaps for application implementation which helps implementation teams get started faster.

entry.title: Vulnerabilities in the X-Content-Type-Options and Referrer-Policy headers
entry.content:
Hello,

To fix the vulnerabilities in the "X-Content-Type-Options" and "Referrer-Policy" headers, we modified the following setting in the DEFAULT profile:

icm/HTTP/mod_0 = PREFIX=/, FILE=$(DIR_GLOBAL)/security/data/icm_filter_rules.txt

Then we entered the following entries in the "icm_filter_rules.txt" file at the OS level:

SetResponseHeader X-Content-Type-Options nosniff SetResponseHeader

Referrer-Policy strict-origin-when-cross-origin

Then we restarted SAP and the ICM.

This change was visible on the BW system (Kernel 7.54, SAP NW 7.50, SAP Basis 750) but not on the SRM system (Kernel 722, SAP NW 7.0, SAP Basis 731): In SMICM, the icm/HTTP/mod_0 parameter is clearly visible in BW but not in SRM. 

Question:

Is this related to the kernel version? How can I correct these settings in the SRM system? 

 

Regards.

I‚Äôm working on a Make-to-Order (MTO) process in SAP S/4HANA where a production order is created automatically at the moment of sales order creation.

Here‚Äôs the current setup and behavior:

  • The finished good (FG) is set to Individual/Collective indicator = 1 (Individual requirements).

  • The BOM components have item category ‚ÄúL‚Äù (stock item) and procurement type ‚ÄúF‚Äù (external procurement).

entry.title: Adaptation Project: How to make filter items mandatory for SAP standard Fiori apps
entry.content:
1. Introduction

SAP standard Fiori apps are used as important tools to support business processes using S/4HANA, and many apps are available that use the implementation technology of the Fiori Elements framework. However, to fully address the company's specific business requirements and specific user needs, it may be necessary to customize the standard app.
Several techniques are offered for Fiori app customization, including metadata extension and UI adaptation. However, if the object to be extended does not support metadata extension, or there may be business requirements that cannot be met by UI adaptation changes. In such cases, a more flexible UI extension method is the Adaptation Project (Developer Adaptation). With Adaptation Project, you can extend standard SAP Fiori elements applications without modification. This means that new application variants can be created and customized to meet unique requirements without modifying the original application.

Adaptation Project: how to change the mandatory input filter in SAP standard Fiori AppAdaptation Project: how to change mandatory input filter in SAP standard Fiori App>In this blog, we will create an Adaptation Project using SAP Business Application Studio to create an Adaptation Project for the requirements that filter field (Plant) defined as mandatory in the SAP Standard Fiori app (F0842A: Manage Purchase Orders). We'll walk you through the specific steps to add Annotation to customize your standard app.

 

2. Implementation method

1. Access SAP Business Application Studio and open the dev space of SAP Fiori.

 

2. Open Folder to access the Projects folder (/home/user/projects/).

 

 

 

3. Open New Project from Template from file and select SAPUI5 Adaptation Project.

 

 

 

4. In System and Application Selection, enter the following, and then click Next to proceed with the settings.

System: Destination to S/4HANA for the extended application
Application: Extended apps (for this blog, Manage Purchase Orders)

 

5. Enter the following information in Project Attributes:

Project Name: Any project name
Application Title: Any app title
Namespace: Auto-generated based on the project name you enter (can be changed if necessary).
Project Folder Path:P auto-populates the path to the rojects folder (you can change it if needed).
SAPUI5 Version: Auto-populates the latest SAPUI5 version (here, you can't change it. If you want to change to the SAPUI5 version installed on S/4HANA, you will need to change the ui5.yaml file after the project is generated. For more information, see SAP KBA:3095848 - How to change SAPUI5 version if problems occur for Adaptation Project in BAS.
Add Deployment Configuration: Yes

 

6. After entering the following information in the Deployment Configuration, click the Finish button to generate the project.

Destination: Auto-populates the Destination selected in System and Application Selection (you can change it if necessary).
Select How You Want to Enter the Package: Choose either Enter Manually / Choose from Existing to select the package for deployment.
Package: Select the package for deployment (screenshot shows a local package as an example).

 

 

 

7. Right-click on the generated project to generate an annotation file from Add Local Annotation File (also available from the Add Local Annotation File button in Application Information).

 

 

 

8. In the Add Local Annotation File, enter the following information:

Target OData Service: mainService (Autofill)
Annotation XML: Create local annotation file from template (if creating a new one) / Select annotation file from workspace (When referencing an existing annotation file)

 

 

9. A new annotation file will be created under webapp/changes/annotations in the project folder, so it will be opened.

 

 

10. Add the following annotation implementation to the annotation file (details of the implementation are described in the next section):

<edmx:Edmx xmlns:edmx="http://docs.oasis-open.org/odata/ns/edmx" Version="4.0">
    <edmx:Reference Uri="https://sap.github.io/odata-vocabularies/vocabularies/Common.xml">
        <edmx:Include Namespace="com.sap.vocabularies.Common.v1" Alias="Common"/>
    </edmx:Reference>
    <edmx:Reference Uri="https://sap.github.io/odata-vocabularies/vocabularies/UI.xml">
        <edmx:Include Namespace="com.sap.vocabularies.UI.v1" Alias="UI"/>
    </edmx:Reference>
    <edmx:Reference Uri="https://sap.github.io/odata-vocabularies/vocabularies/Communication.xml">
        <edmx:Include Namespace="com.sap.vocabularies.Communication.v1" Alias="Communication"/>
    </edmx:Reference>
    <edmx:Reference Uri="/sap/opu/odata/sap/MM_PUR_PO_MAINT_V2_SRV/$metadata">
        <edmx:Include Namespace="MM_PUR_PO_MAINT_V2_SRV"/>
    </edmx:Reference>
    <edmx:Reference Uri="/sap/opu/odata/iwfnd/catalogservice;v=2/Vocabularies(TechnicalName='%2FIWBEP%2FVOC_CAPABILITIES',Version='0001',SAP__Origin='')/$value">
          <edmx:Include Namespace="Org.OData.Capabilities.V1" Alias="Capabilities"/>
    </edmx:Reference>
    <edmx:DataServices>
        <Schema xmlns="http://docs.oasis-open.org/odata/ns/edm" Namespace="local_1760320506713">
            <Annotations Target="MM_PUR_PO_MAINT_V2_SRV.MM_PUR_PO_MAINT_V2_SRV_Entities/C_PurchaseOrderTP"> 
                <Annotation Term="Capabilities.FilterRestrictions"> 
                    <Record> 
                        <PropertyValue Property="RequiresFilter" Bool="true"/> 
                        <PropertyValue Property="RequiredProperties"> 
                            <Collection> 
                                <PropertyPath>Plant</PropertyPath> 
                            </Collection> 
                        </PropertyValue> 
                    </Record> 
                </Annotation> 
            </Annotations>
        </Schema>
    </edmx:DataServices>
</edmx:Edmx>

 

 

 

11. Add definitions for your app to reference the app's additional annotations in the manifest.appdescr_variant file.

 

 

{
  "fileName": "manifest",
  "layer": "CUSTOMER_BASE",
  "fileType": "appdescr_variant",
  "reference": "ui.ssuite.s2p.mm.pur.po.manage.st.s1",
  "id": "customer.zapp.f0842a",
  "namespace": "apps/ui.ssuite.s2p.mm.pur.po.manage.st.s1/appVariants/customer.zapp.f0842a/",
  "version": "0.1.0",
  "content": [
    {
      "changeType": "appdescr_ui5_addNewModelEnhanceWith",
      "content": {
        "modelId": "i18n"
      },
      "texts": {
        "i18n": "i18n/i18n.properties"
      }
    },
    {
      "changeType": "appdescr_ui5_addNewModelEnhanceWith",
      "content": {
        "modelId": "@i18n"
      },
      "texts": {
        "i18n": "i18n/i18n.properties"
      }
    },
    {
      "changeType": "appdescr_ui5_addNewModelEnhanceWith",
      "content": {
        "modelId": "i18n|sap.suite.ui.generic.template.ListReport|C_PurchaseOrderTP"
      },
      "texts": {
        "i18n": "i18n/ListReport/C_PurchaseOrderTP/i18n.properties"
      }
    },
    {
      "changeType": "appdescr_ui5_addNewModelEnhanceWith",
      "content": {
        "modelId": "i18n|sap.suite.ui.generic.template.ObjectPage|C_PurchaseOrderTP"
      },
      "texts": {
        "i18n": "i18n/ObjectPage/C_PurchaseOrderTP/i18n.properties"
      }
    },
    {
      "changeType": "appdescr_ui5_addNewModelEnhanceWith",
      "content": {
        "modelId": "i18n|sap.suite.ui.generic.template.ObjectPage|C_PurchaseOrderItemTP"
      },
      "texts": {
        "i18n": "i18n/ObjectPage/C_PurchaseOrderItemTP/i18n.properties"
      }
    },
    {
      "changeType": "appdescr_ui5_addNewModelEnhanceWith",
      "content": {
        "modelId": "i18n|sap.suite.ui.generic.template.ObjectPage|C_PurchaseOrderLimitItemTP"
      },
      "texts": {
        "i18n": "i18n/ObjectPage/C_PurchaseOrderLimitItemTP/i18n.properties"
      }
    },
    {
      "changeType": "appdescr_ui5_setMinUI5Version",
      "content": {
        "minUI5Version": "1.114.9"
      }
    },
    {
      "changeType": "appdescr_app_setTitle",
      "content": {},
      "texts": {
        "i18n": "i18n/i18n.properties"
      }
    },
    { 
      "changeType": "appdescr_app_addAnnotationsToOData", 
      "content": { 
        "dataSourceId": "mainService", 
        "annotations": [ "customer.myAnno" ], 
        "annotationsInsertPosition": "END", 
        "dataSource": { 
          "customer.myAnno": { 
            "uri": "changes/annotations/annotation_1760320506713.xml", 
            "type": "ODataAnnotation" 
          } 
        } 
      } 
    }
  ]
}

 

 

 

12. Right-click on the webapp > preview the app from the Preview Application (also from the Preview Application button in the Application Information).

 

 

13. Verify that the plant field is a required field.

 

 

14. Deploy the app from Deploy Application by right-clicking on the webapp (also from the Deploy button in Application Information).

 

 

 

15. Deployed apps (app variants) can be used by end users by defining Semantic objects, semantic actions, SAPUI5 Components, tiles, etc. in the Fiori technical catalog and referencing them from the business catalog and business roles.

Semantic Object: Any semantic Object
Action: Any semantic action
SAPUI5 Component ID: Namespace when generating a project in Step.5

 

3. Explanation of implementation details

1. Local Annotation fileÔºàannotation_xxx.xmlÔºâ

A local annotation file is a file that implements annotated extensions to the OData service used by standard Fiori apps. The description in the file is based on the syntax of OData, and there are the following restrictions (some excerpts).

  • edmx:Edmx
    • It is the root element, and between <edmx:Edmx> ~ </edmx:Edmx>, it writes the syntax. The definition of <edmx:Edmx> must include a description of Version and <edmx:DataServices> element.
  • edmx:Reference
    • Specifies an external Common Schema Definition Language (CSDL) document that is referenced in the annotation file. The child element edmx:Reference must contain a description of the Uri (the referenced URI) and at least one edmx:Include element.
  • edmx:Include
    • Specifies the schema under the CSDL document to be referenced. Namespace. You can also specify Alias.
  • edmx:Dataservices
    • An element that describes the properties of the Annotation, etc., and must contain a single Schema element. Write annotations in the Schema element.
  • Annotations
    • Specify the target attribute that contains the EntitySet name of the OData service you want to extend. It must contain at least one Annotation element.

According to these syntax, we have implemented that the filter field of the plant must be entered.

  • Identifying Targets for Expansion
    The implementation of this blog requires the following Target information:
  1. TargetÔºöMM_PUR_PO_MAINT_V2_SRV.MM_PUR_PO_MAINT_V2_SRV_Entities/C_PurchaseOrderTP
    • OData Service Name: MM_PUR_PO_MAINT_V2_SRV
    • EntityContainer Name: MM_PUR_PO_MAINT_V2_SRV_Entities
    • EntitySet Name: C_PurchaseOrderTP (*Not EntityType Name)
  2. PropertyPathÔºöPlant
  3. OData Service Name: SAP Fiori Apps Reference LibraryÔºàhttps://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#) to search for the Fiori app you want to expand. The OData used in the Fiori app is listed in the OData Service under "Configuration" in the "IMPLEMENTATION INFORMATION" tab of the app's page.

4. EntityContainer Name
Check the metadata of the OData service using the app (https://<IP Adress>:<Port Number>/sap/opu/odata/sap/ MM_PUR_PO_MAINT_V2_SRV/$metadata)„ÄÇ
You can find the EntityContainer name by searching for EntityContainer.

 

5. EntitySet name
When you start the Fiori app "Manage Purchase Orders", if you check the Preview/Response of the request to manifest.appdescr in the browser's developer tools, the entity set used for the List Report is "C_ PurchaseOrderTP".

6. PropertyPath
You can identify the item name (PropertyPath) by checking the definition of the target entity set in the metadata of the target OData service.

 

  • Setting Extension Target and Annotation Change Properties
    1.  manifest.json load the metadata of the OData service "MM_PUR_PO_MAINT_V2_SRV" used for "Purchase Order Management" and set the CDS View with the field to be extended by annotation to Target.
    2. The implementation uses FilterRestrictions to change the properties "RequiresFilter" and "RequiredProperties", so that the FilterRestrictions are included in "Org.OData.Capabilities.V1". vocabulary is referenced by the specified alias.

 

2. manifest.appdescr_variant.json

manifest.appdescr_variant.json is a file that describes the objects available in the original app, and many settings refer to the manifest information of the standard app. If you want to add a local annotation file, set the following properties:

"dataSourceId": A property that specifies the OData service of interest, in this scenario it is "mainService".
"annotations": Specify the name of the annotation for the OData data source "mainService" that you specified. The name must start with "customer" (for example, "customer.myAnno").
"annotationsInsertPosition": "END". If not, they may be disabled by the server user and have no effect at all.
"dataSource": "Specify the annotation name that starts with "customer". If you specify a local annotation file created with "uri" and add "type" to OData, it will be "ODataAnnotation".

 

4. Summary

In this article, we have shown you how to create an Adaptation Project in SAP Business Application Studio and add Local Annotation to make filter fields mandatory. In addition to making filters mandatory, the Adaptation Project allows you to extend your annotation implementation, extend your controller, and add custom XML fragments. For more information about the Adaptation Project, please refer to the documentation in the References section.

 

References

SAP Help: Extending an SAP Fiori Application for an SAP S/4HANA or SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
SAP Blog: Extending SAP-delivered SAP Fiori elements apps using adaptation projects to create SAP S/4HANA app variants
SAP KBA: https://me.sap.com/notes/3285957

entry.title: Accruals & Deductions for Casual/Hourly Workers
entry.content:
Hello SAP SuccessFactors Time Tracking Experts,

Is there any standard solution in SF to cover the accruals and deductions for casual/daily workers (especially in Retail sector across different countries).

Scenario : 

1. They do not have a fixed work schedule. So normally with 0 working hours across all days.  ---- So work schedule with all days as non-working days to be configured in SF.

2. Based on the time recorded in the time tracking, system to calculate the accruals for those employees. (So if worked 5 days 4 hours each in the last month, gets pro-rated accruals accordingly in days/hours based on business requirement). ---- Standard behavior with accrual logic based on Recorded Times.

3. But how can the deductions be handled when employee is applying for a vacation?

-- If accruals are in days,  and when employee applies for a leave for 15.10.2025, system will deduct 0 days as no planned working hours on that day, or 1 day if deduction is based on calendar days. But both are wrong, as normally the business requirement is to average out the no. of hours worked in the last 12 months and accordingly calculate the deduction quantity. (However it is not possible via the counting configuration to determine the average hours worked based on timesheet).

-- -- If accruals are in hours,  and when employee applies for a leave for 15.10.2025, system will not allow to put leave in hours as only full day absences are allowed for non-working days. And if a full day absence is applied, how will system know how many hours to deduct? Same problem with counting rule above.   In this case, only thing i can think of is to have another custom field asking employee to put the no.of hours he wants to request, and then use that in the counting rule as deduction.

Is there any standard way or any recommendations of handling this in SF?

@NeeleshKamath  @Volker_Ruof @PriyankaAgarwal 

Regards,

Mohit Somani

entry.title: How to Add a New Tab in ESS Portal for Time Event (Punch In/Out)
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

I am working on Employee Self-Service (ESS) in SAP Portal and I want to add a new tab in the ESS overview for Time Event, where employees can view and record Punch In / Punch Out times.

Here‚Äôs what I have done so far:

  1. Created a Web Dynpro ABAP Component (Z_HRESS_TIME_EVENT) with:

    • From Date / To Date input

    • Punch In / Punch Out buttons

    • Table showing history of time events

  2. Exposed it as a Web Dynpro Application (Z_HRESS_TIME_EVENT_APP) in SE80, which runs perfectly when tested directly.

  3. In LPD_CUST, I created a new folder under the same Role / Instance as other tabs (Working Time, Personal Information, Benefits) and added my application there.

Problem / Question:

When I log in to the ESS Portal, I do not see my new tab. I understand that the Portal shows tabs via iViews and role assignments.

I want to know:

  • How can I create an iView for my Web Dynpro application and assign it to the ESS Role / Workset in the Portal?

  • Can this be done without Portal Admin access, or do I need someone with admin rights?

  • Are there best practices for adding Time Event tabs in ESS overview for punch in/out functionality?

Any guidance, example steps, or references would be very helpful!

Thanks in advance.

#SAP #ABAP #WebDynpro #ESS #SAPPortal #EmployeeSelfService #LPD_CUST #FPM

entry.title: Compatibility for DMIS 2020 SP10
entry.content:
Dear support,

 

Is the scenario below supported?

Upgrade ECC6.0 to SAP S/4 PERSON_NAME DIGITS (DMIS DIGITS SP10)
Upgrade DMIS on LTRS 1.0 for S/4 PERSON_NAME from DMIS DIGITS SP05 to DMIS 2020SP10
Upgrade DMIS on CARAB 5.0 FPS 05 from DMIS DIGITS SP05 to DMIS 2020SP10

Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Compatibility for DMIS 2020 SP10
entry.content:
Dear Customer, 

 

Yes, the scenario is supported. 

Since DMIS 2020 SP10 is equivalent to DMIS 2018 SP14, it is possible to check note below:

3657956 - Release Information SLT - DMIS 2018 SP14

 

Best Regards, 

SAP Support.
